Award.AwardTitle: Noyce Mathematics and Science Teaching Scholarship Program at Siena College

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration: The Phase I Robert Noyce Teacher Education Scholarship program at Siena College recruits, certifies, and retains twenty-one unique high-achieving STEM majors to become teachers in high-need middle and high schools. In years 2, 3, and 4 of the project, seven new Noyce Scholars are selected and supported in their junior and senior years with $20,000 scholarships. A number of faculty from several STEM disciplines participate in the project. The Siena Noyce Scholarship program benefits from partnership with the Schenectady City School District and several additional local schools that have significant high-need populations. The program implements a cohort strategy that builds on rigorous research-based undergraduate STEM programs. The program implements the viewpoint that STEM teachers should balance the content of authentic science, which should be the same for all students in a particular major, with practical preparation in education. The model also addresses and tests the importance of research experiences and interdisciplinary learning for STEM education majors as the basis for excellence in teaching. Assessments are measuring the effectiveness of attracting and retaining students, preparing them to teach in high-need schools, and retaining them as teachers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Siena College Noyce Teacher Scholar Program

The NSF Robert Noyce Teacher Scholarship Program is designed to increase the number of qualified science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) majors becoming qualified teachers, particularly serving high-needs districts. Siena College proposed to leverage its strong STEM education and undergraduate research programs to benefit the Noyce Scholar Program. Under the Siena College Noyce Teacher Scholar Program, Noyce Scholars would be awarded up to two $20,000 scholarships. The scholarships are technically loans that can be forgiven by completing two years of teaching in a high-needs district for each $20,000 awarded.

Main objective and results: Siena College proposed that 21 students, in groups of three cohorts of seven, would be Noyce Scholars and receive 42 scholarships, issued during the students? junior and senior years. The original proposal aimed for 12 mathematics majors and 9 students majoring in biology, chemistry, biochemistry, or physics. Overall, the Siena College Noyce Teacher Scholar Program came close to achieving its objectives. Twenty-two students in four cohorts were awarded full or partial scholarships and 14 mathematics and 3 science students completed the program. Two outstanding candidates left the program as their final semester was starting. Both were double majors in mathematics and computer science. Veteran high school teachers actually advised them to avoid teaching and they followed this advice. Two physics students in the first of our four cohorts left the program after one year in order to pursue an academic program that would prepare them for graduate work in physics. 

Program Features:

1. Use of a cohort model. Before applying to our Noyce program, students applied and were accepted into a pre-Noyce summer program. They stayed on campus and enrolled in a required education course, commuted to an intense field experience at a local urban high school every day for five weeks, participated in a weekly seminar, and shared their experiences in a required blog. The summer program produced strong, supportive groups of scholars. We anticipated that half of the students who participated in the summer program would apply to be Siena Noyce scholars. All but one of the 23 participants applied and were accepted into our program.

2. Strong field experience. During Siena?s first summer session, Siena students in the summer program, which took place during the last five weeks of the high school academic year, spent an average of four hours per day at Schenectady High School working with high school students in classes for two hours and tutoring students after school for two hours. The total of 80 field-experience hours per participant is well beyond any of the other field experiences required at Siena before the full-time semester of student-teaching.  Participants recognized the value of this experience. They were able to develop relationships with teachers and students and cited daily attendance at the same time of day as the principle reason for this. It would be difficult if not impossible to replicate this experience during the Siena?s regular academic year.

3. Mentoring from experienced high school mathematics and science teachers. During the summer, our scholars worked interactively with multiple teachers in a high-needs school. The mentoring was very valuable to their professional development.

4. Mentoring from Siena College faculty members. Each participant also had a Siena faculty member as a mentor. The project faculty members mentored two of the participants during the summer experience. This included shadowing each mentee for about two hours per week while they were working at Schenectady High School. (We did not want to overwhelm the school with four or more project personnel each day so we each went to the high school one day per week to shadow our mentees.)

5. During their years as undergraduates, most of our Noyce scholars attended and co-presented at multiple conferences. Some of these were Noyce meetings. Most were local or state conferences for STEM educators.

6. All of the mathematics scholars were required to complete a strong minor in computer science (CS) which included a course on teaching CS at the pre-college level. This course was offered during the summer session following the semester the students completed their first methods course on teaching mathematics. It was team-taught by four members of the CS department.

7. All of the science scholars were required to participate in an independent research project with a Siena faculty member. The students reported that these experiences were beneficial in helping them understand the importance of teaching authentic science.

Dissemination: The products that were developed and the experiences gained during this project were shared at over a hundred conferences for STEM educators including several workshop sessions at the annual Noyce conference in Washington, D.C.
